Â p459Â Biographical Notes

(continued:Â CâE)

JoaquÃ­n Cabezas GarcÃ­a (1867â1948), a graduate of the men's normal school of SantiagoÂ (1886), was sent abroad three years later to study the Swedish system of physical and manual education, and continued his studies in Belgium in psychology and pedagogy. InÂ 1893 he was made professor of manual training in the normal school and also taught gymnastics in the National Institute. He created the School of Physical Education inÂ 1906 and reorganized it inÂ 1919, thus making it peculiarly his institution. He is the author of numerous textbooks and has played an important part in all educational activities. â F,Â II,Â 304; Hoy, AugustÂ 27, 1936, p16.

AndrÃ©s Avelino CÃ¡ceres (1833â1924) was born at Ayacucho, Peru. As a youth he served under RamÃ³n Castilla and fromÂ 1857 toÂ 1860 he was military attachÃ© at Paris. During the war against Chile he became a general and after the fall of Lima he was provisional president. InÂ 1886 he became regular president and after an interval was again suggested for the office but declined because of intense opposition. He held diplomatic posts in France, Great Britain, and Italy. â E,Â X,Â 256.

Narciso Campero (1815â1896) was born in Valle deÂ Tojo, Bolivia, and studied law in Argentina, but he returned to his native country to fight against Chile. He completed his law studies in the University of Chuquisaca (now Sucre), pursued military studies in Europe, and took an active part in the uprisings against the dictators, CÃ³rdoba and Melgarejo. By successive stages he rose to the rank of general of division, minister of war, and supreme commander of the Bolivian army. During the war with Chile, in which he gave a good account of himself, he became president of Bolivia and in that capacity he had to accept the Treaty ofÂ 1884. He then retired to private life. â E,Â X,Â 1265.

Enrique Campino (1794â1877?), who was picked out by the conspirators to head the revolt, was himself a member of congress and came from a prominent family. His military record, however, was bad and his name inspired no confidence. He was later implicated in the conspiracy of Quillota but was saved from execution (see p269). He held the office of senator inÂ 1863. â B,Â XV,Â 131â144; F,Â II,Â 320â323.

Estanislao delÂ Canto Arteaga (1840â1923) was born in Quillota and educated in the Military School, which he entered inÂ 1856. Beginning his service inÂ 1859, the year of the second uprising against Montt, he took part in the battle of Cerro Grande (see p299) and engaged in numerous campaigns against the Araucanians. As colonel he participated in the Peruvian campaigns and inÂ 1889 he was prefect of police in Santiago. Relegated to Tacna by president Balmaceda, he was in an Â p460Â excellent position to aid the revolutionists against that executive. He became general of division inÂ 1891, was sent on a military mission to Europe inÂ 1892, and forced to retire from the army inÂ 1897. His later years were embittered by jealousy of his associates. â F,Â II,Â 343â344.

Ignacio deÂ laÂ Carrera (1747â1818) was born in Santiago, his mother being the daughter of a member of the audiencia of Chile. He had a restless disposition, and his father sent him to Peru where he passed some seven years in Lima; and then to Spain, where he lived for aÂ year and aÂ half in CÃ¡diz, devoted to business. His wealth and aristocratic connections made him a valuable adherent of the patriotic cause to which his three sons were martyrs. See Miguel Luis AmunÃ¡tegui, Camilo HernÃ¡ndez (2Â vols., Santiago, 1889), I,Â 5â7; J.Â T.Â Medina, "BibliografÃ­a deÂ DonÂ JosÃ© Miguel Carrera," in Rev.Â chil. deÂ hist. yÂ geog., XL,Â 326â371; F,Â II,Â 364.

JosÃ© Miguel Carrera (1785â1821), the first president of Chile, was born in Santiago and executed in Mendoza. His parents wished him to have a literary career, but, having decided military tastes, he entered the cavalry regiment of Farnesio in Spain and distinguished himself during the war against the French, rising to the rank of captain. On learning of the outbreak of the revolution he returned to Chile and after the fall of MartÃ­nez deÂ Rozas took the conspicuous part detailed in the preceding pages. As a consequence of the rivalry with O'Higgins, he did not support the latter in the battle of Rancagua. After this reverse he went to Buenos Aires inÂ 1816 and thence to the United States. He returned to Buenos Aires inÂ 1816 and later organized a plan to seize the supreme power in Chile, but was captured and shot. AÂ monument was erected to him in Santiago inÂ 1864. â E,Â XI,Â 1324; B,Â VIII,Â 392. See Collier and Cruz, LaÂ primera misiÃ³n deÂ losÂ Estados Unidos deÂ AmÃ©rica en Chile, passim; Luis Galdames, LaÂ evoluciÃ³n constitucional deÂ Chile, 1810â192[6], I,Â 189â191; VicuÃ±a Mackenna, ElÂ ostracismo deÂ losÂ Carreras; for the Diario militar of Carrera see "ColecciÃ³n deÂ historiadores iÂ de documentos relativos a laÂ independencia deÂ Chile," Vol.Â I. AÂ description of Carreras' Diario militar is to be found in B,Â IX,Â 634â637, especially n.Â 9 on p636. See also ibid., n.Â 14, on pp610â615; Agusto Iglesias, JosÃ© Miguel Carrera. LaÂ rebeliÃ³n armada en AmÃ©rica (Santiago, 1934).

Mariano Casanova Casanova (1833â1906) was born in Santiago, began his studies in the National Institute, and finished them in the Conciliar Seminary. He early displayed talents that justified his receiving orders as presbyter and being chosen professor in the seminary and member of the faculty of sacred sciences and theology in the University of Chile. InÂ 1861 he received the degree of attorney from the university. InÂ 1865 he journeyed to Europe and then took up parish Â p461Â duties in Valparaiso, where he was distinguished for his pulpit eloquence and for a polemical controversy with the Protestant, David Trumbull. InÂ 1888 he founded the Catholic University of Santiago. InÂ 1886 he became archbishop of Santiago and four years later tried to harmonize congress and Balmaceda. Remaining neutral during the civil war, he added to his prestige by a second visit to Europe inÂ 1894, during which he had an audience with the pope. InÂ 1895 he completed a code of laws for the Chilean church; inÂ 1896, made a spectacular fraternal visit to Argentina; and, inÂ 1899, brought about a meeting of all the higher clergy of South America. â F,Â II,Â 377â378.

Carlos Casanueva Opazo (1874â1957)​a received his degree in law inÂ 1896 but, preferring the Church, he was ordained as presbyter inÂ 1900. Although holding aÂ few parish charges, his main efforts have been in the field of religious education and journalism and in behalf of the unprivileged classes. InÂ 1920 he became rector in the Catholic University where he improved and broadened its scientific courses. He opened its classes to women inÂ 1924, to adults inÂ 1926, and at various times has organized conferences on topics of general business interest. Modest, industrious, and talented, he has done much to make his institution deservedly popular.â F,Â II,Â 381.

CaupolicÃ¡n (d.Â 1558), the Araucanian chief, was probably born near PalmaiquÃ©n in the early part of the sixteenth century. After defeating Valdivia and Villagra, as narrated in the text, he himself suffered three disastrous routs, was taken prisoner, and barbarously executed. It is claimed that he tried without success to save Valdivia from torture and death and that he on his part offered to return Valdivia's skull, sword, and gold chain if he were spared. The failure of his messenger to bring back these articles meant his own death at CaÃ±ete. His fame apparently is due more to the verses of Ercilla than to his own skill and valor, although he possessed those qualities to a remarkable degree. Nicanor Plaza (q.v.) has made a famous statue of this chieftain. â E,Â XII,Â 645.

Thomas Cavendish (1555?â1592) was a native of Trimley St.Â Martin, Suffolk, England. Like many of his contemporaries he early took to piracy. His first considerable voyage was inÂ 1585 in the company of SirÂ Richard Grenville, who sailed under the direction of SirÂ Walter Raleigh to attempt the first settlement of Virginia. After returning to England, he sought to imitate the exploit of SirÂ Francis Drake and in July,Â 1586, set out with a fleet of three ships on what proved to be the second English circumnavigation of the globe. Later in that year he discovered and named Port Desire, near the Strait of Magellan. On MarchÂ 30, 1586, he reached the Bay of Quintero on the Chilean coast; at Arica, some time later, he plundered and burned Â p462Â several Spanish ships; and, continuing his plunder, burning course along the entire South American coast and across the Pacific, he finally reached Plymouth on SeptemberÂ 15, 1588. His arrival aroused great enthusiasm among his fellow countrymen. He attempted to repeat his exploit but died at sea on this voyage. See Dictionary of National Biography, IX,Â 358â363.

JosÃ© Ignacio Cienfuegos Astorga (1762â1845) was born and educated in Santiago and became curate in Talca inÂ 1790. He became active in the movement for independence and suffered exile on the island of Juan FernÃ¡ndez. On his return he served as archdeacon in the cathedral at Santiago, was proprietary senator under O'Higgins, was a member of various congresses, and was interested in promoting education. InÂ 1827 he founded the Instituto literario of Talca, which afterwards became the liceo of that city. In addition to the journey to Rome mentioned in the text, he was later, because of charges made by the papal delegate, forced to go to Rome to clear himself. This he did successfully and later became bishop of ConcepciÃ³n. Retiring from this charge inÂ 1837, he spent the rest of his life in Talca. Barros Arana gives an account of his mission to Rome. â B,Â XIII,Â 568â577; F,Â II,Â 400.

AbdÃ³n Cifuentes Espinosa (1836â1928) was born in SanÂ Felipe, province of Aconcagua. Coming from a family of moderate means it was necessary for him to struggle hard for professional and political position. He was educated in the liceo of SanÂ Felipe and in the National Institute at which inÂ 1862 he became professor of history. He early showed marked literary aptitude as well as ultramontane tendencies and was soon regarded as the ready scribe and fiery orator of the conservative party. He was one of the founders and a long-time contributing editor of ElÂ independente, a conservative organ. He helped organize the UniÃ³n catÃ³lica deÂ Chile, a charitable and cultural society of the Catholic Church and was one of the founders of the Catholic University of Santiago. InÂ 1889 he was made professor of public constitutional law on its staff. InÂ 1867 he became subsecretary in the ministry which carried through the legislation noted in the text (on p313). He was elected deputy from Rancagua and in congress at once became the chief orator of the conservative party, a leader­ship that he maintained to the end of a long political career. In the revolution ofÂ 1891 he espoused the side of congress and with the success of the revolutionists became senator. His literary output was largely polemic in character and much of it has not survived the papers in which it was published. Characterized in his early years as the spoiled child of the party, he lived to become its grand old man, honored and respected even by those who disagreed with his political and religious viewsÂ â Â p463Â E,Â XIII,Â 191; F,Â II,Â 402â405; Justo and Domingo Arteaga Alemparte, LosÂ constituyentes chilenos deÂ 1870 in "Biblioteca deÂ escritores deÂ Chile," II,Â 422â425. His addresses have been collected in three volumes, ColecciÃ³n deÂ discursos deÂ AbdÃ³n Cifuentes (Santiago, 1916). The Diario ilustrado of Santiago, of Sunday, MayÂ 16, 1926, published a two-page sketch of his life, on the occasion of his ninetieth birthday.

Thomas Cochrane (1775â1860), Earl of Dundonald, was a native of Anesfield, Lanarkshire, Scotland. He lived a varied and tumultuous life. Entering the British navy inÂ 1795, he filled the years of his early service with brilliant exploits at sea and continual wrangling with his associates and superiors, varied by equally stormy political experiences. Despite his popularity with the masses, he failed to gain due promotion and was unjustly accused of fraud, fined, and imprisoned. This punishment, it seemed, was due more to his independent course in parliament than to any real guilt. Hence he was in a mood to enter the Chilean service inÂ 1818. He soon made Chile the mistress of the southern Pacific, but received no compensation for this service. He even lost his share of the prize money for the daring capture of Valdivia. Nor did he fare better in the Brazilian or Grecian service, although the former bestowed a marquisate on him. Later he was restored to rank and partial compensation in the British navy, in which service he became vice-admiral inÂ 1842 and admiral inÂ 1854. In his later years he distinguished himself by his mechanical inventions. As a commander he prevailed in personal combat, in which he was able to do much with small means. His career presents an injudicious admixture of political independence and bad temper, of honesty, skill, and daring, of insubordination, and popular appeal. â F,Â II,Â 416. His own account of his life appears in Narrative of Services in the Liberation of Chile, Peru, and Brazil. See B,Â XII,Â 173, etÂ seq.; Pilling, The Emancipation of South America, chap.Â xxii; and Dictionary of National Biography, XI,Â 165â175.

Carlos Condell deÂ laÂ Haza (1843â1887), born in Valparaiso, was partly of Scotch ancestry. After studying in the colegio of the French Fathers and in England, he entered the Naval School at Valparaiso inÂ 1858. InÂ 1865 he showed his qualities as a fighter as well as seaman by capturing the Spanish vessel Covadonga. The same qualities gave him a victory over the Peruvian cruiser Independencia, in the battle of Iquique (see p327). He died at QuilpuÃ©, with the rank of vice-admiral. â E,Â XIV,Â 1066; F,Â II,Â 428â429.

SimÃ³n deÂ Cordes (d.Â ca.Â 1600), mariner, was born in Antwerp. As a young merchant, he resided for aÂ year in Lisbon and married there. Â p464Â Acting as vice-admiral in the Dutch navy, inÂ 1598 he was sent with a fleet to attack the Spaniards in the South Seas, and was later reinforced by two other Dutch expeditions. One report represents him as having been killed by natives on the island of SantaÂ MarÃ­a, near ConcepciÃ³n; another states that he disappeared enÂ route to Japan. â E,Â XV,Â 554; B,Â III,Â 305â320; IV,Â 102â114.

Rafael Correa MuÃ±oz (1863â1959),​b born in Santiago, was a pupil of Pedro Lira and has attracted attention because of his animal pictures. His paintings have been exhibited in Paris, in Buffalo, and in Argentina. His exhibition in Santiago inÂ 1924 attracted wide attention. InÂ 1926 he was elected president of the Sociedad deÂ Bellas Artes of Chile âÂ F,Â II,Â 449.

Jean Gustave Courcelle-Seneuil (1813â1892) was born in Seneuil, France.​c In youth and early manhood he combined work in metallurgy with his studies in economics. AfterÂ 1848 he served as subordinate in the treasury office, but with the establishment of the empire he went to South America and for ten years (1853â1863) taught political enemy in the law school of the University of Chile. After his return to France he served on the Council of State inÂ 1879 and inÂ 1882 entered the Academy of Moral and Political Science. While in Chile he edited the Ley deÂ Bancos (Banking Law). Original in his concepts, he sought to give a scientific background to economics and to separate theory from practice. He strongly defended free trade and favored decentralization in government. He died in Paris. â E,Â XV,Â 1358; F,Â II,Â 467â468.

Miguel Cruchaga Tocornal (1867â1949)​d became an advocate inÂ 1889 and took the part of congress in the revolution ofÂ 1891. He began to teach law in the Catholic University inÂ 1892 and in the University of Chile four years later. He was deputy from Melipilla (1900â1906) and as such became prominent in matters of finance and foreign affairs. He became minister of the treasury inÂ 1903 and of the interior inÂ 1905. He served continuously as minister and ambassador abroad fromÂ 1908 toÂ 1927, when, having failed to settle the long-standing dispute with Peru, he temporarily withdrew in favor of Carlos DÃ¡vila (see p410),​e until Alessandri again brought him into office. In the course of his diplomatic activities he was frequently called to serve upon mixed commissions where other countries were involved. His textbook on international law has been deservedly popular in Chile. He has also written numerous pamphlets on diplomatic and financial questions and has been a member of important international gatherings. â F,Â II,Â 484â486; Hoy, DecemberÂ 23, 1932, p8; AugustÂ 30, 1935, p3; JanuaryÂ 14, 1937, p35.

JosÃ© MarÃ­a deÂ laÂ Cruz Prieto (1801â1875) was born in ConcepciÃ³n, Â p465Â saw service under Carrera, and after the disaster at Rancagua (see p184) emigrated to Mendoza with other fugitive revolutionists, and there joined SanÂ MartÃ­n. After the battles of Chacabuco and MaipÃº, in which he fought bravely, he assisted as secretary of the committee that organized the first Peruvian expedition, and occupied numerous subordinate military posts. He was twice in the cabinet as minister of war and marine, served as governor of Valparaiso and intendant of ConcepciÃ³n, and deputy and senator. He was general in chief of the army in south Chile, when he was put forward as presidential candidate against Montt, but after the battle at Loncomilla he retired to private life. â E,Â XVI,Â 643; F,Â II,Â 493â495.

William Dampier (1652â1711) cruised along the coast of California inÂ 1685 and afterward sailed to the Philippines and the coast of China, arriving in England on SeptemberÂ 16, 1691. Dampier made another voyage inÂ 1704, returning inÂ 1707, and in the following year was commissioned as pilot on an expedition with Woodes Rogers around the world, returning inÂ 1711. His own writings form the best source for his expeditions. Also see Early Voyages to Australia (R.Â H.Â Major,Â ed. London, 1859), Hakluyt Society Publications, 1stÂ Series, Vol.Â XXV, p99â111, 134â164. Dampier's career connects him with earlier filibustering enterprises and the more regular naval and scientific work of the eighteenth century. Moreover, he was able to write of his adventures in a clear, entertaining, and convincing style. His voyages embraced the East Indies, the China coast, Australia, the West Indies, and the coasts of both Americas, where he had already made two extensive forays before undertaking the more regular voyages during the War of Spanish Succession, in which SelkirkÂ (q.v.) figures. See Willard Hallam Bonner, Captain William Dampier: Buccaneer-Author (Stanford University, 1934).

Carlos DÃ¡vila Espinoza (1884â1955),​f native of LosÂ Angeles, known especially as editor and director of LaÂ naciÃ³n (1917â1927) and of LosÂ tiempos, has through these publications revolutionized the press of Chile. As ambassador to the United States (1927â1931) he made his country and its resources better known and increased the nitrate sales. After his short and troubled presidency he took up newspaper work in NewÂ York. He was noted for his moderate socialistic ideas. â F,Â II,Â 541; Hoy, JulyÂ 8, 1932, p4; SeptemberÂ 16, 1932, p8.

HilariÃ³n Daza (nÃ©Â GrasolÃ©. 1840â1894) was born in Sucre and adopted his maternal name of Daza. His uncle gave him a rudimentary education, after which the nephew entered the army. InÂ 1864 he gained the confidence of the Bolivian tyrant Melgarejo, and inÂ 1870 gained popularity by starting a revolt against his patron. InÂ 1873 he took Â p466Â over the government and initiated some beneficial reforms. In the early stages of the war with Chile, showing himself inept, his soldiers deposed him. He ranks as close second to Bolivia's worst president, Melgarejo.Âº â E,Â XXVI,Â 1378; Dennis, Tacna and Arica, passim.

SebastiÃ¡n DÃ­az,Â O.Â P. (1741âca.Â 1813), a native of Santiago and a graduate inÂ 1763 of the University of SanÂ Felipe, was a well-known Dominican friar, the second prior of his order in Chile, and one of the most learned teachers of the University of SanÂ Felipe. His principal work, noted in the text, was probably published in Lima inÂ 1782 but failed to present the ideas of the author clearly or in agreeable form; hence it was superseded when better books came in from the outside. â M,Â p240. See also J.Â T.Â Medina, Historia deÂ laÂ literatura colonial deÂ Chile, II,Â 533â547.

Juan DÃ­az deÂ SolÃ­s (d. 1516) was born at Lebrija near Seville. He had already served in the Casa daÂ India of Portugal before he was selected by the Spanish government inÂ 1508, together with Vicente YÃ¡Ã±ez PinzÃ³n, to course the American Atlantic coast from Honduras to the fortieth parallel of south latitude. InÂ 1512 he was made pilot major of Spain to succeed Amerigo Vespucci. InÂ 1513 he began preparations for a western voyage to the Spice Islands but did not leave until the end ofÂ 1515 and early in the following year discovered LaÂ Plata River where he met his death. â E,Â XVIII,Â 895.

Ignacio Domeyko (1802â1889) was born in Lithuania. As a boy he beheld the march of Napoleon's forces against Russia; as a youth he and his intimate friend Adam Mickiewicz attended the University of Wilna, where with other students they frequently clashed with the Russian authorities. He also studied in Vienna. InÂ 1831 he joined in the futile revolt that still further enslaved his native Poland and forced him into a Paris exile. InÂ 1837 he left Paris for Chile under contract to teach chemistry, mineralogy,Âº and other natural sciences in the liceo of LaÂ Serena. InÂ 1856 he took up his professional work in the capital, and inÂ 1876 became rector of the University of Chile. He was at one and the same time a scientist, a sincere Christian, and a poet. â F,Â II,Â 585. See also M.Â L.Â AmunÃ¡tegui, Ensayos biogrÃ¡ficos, I,Â 185â415.

Francis Drake (ca.Â 1545â1596) had, strictly speaking, begun his expeditions â whether piratical or not â long beforeÂ 1578. InÂ 1565, at the age of twenty, he had made a voyage to the coast of Guinea under SirÂ John Hawkins, his kinsman and mentor. He likewise accompanied Hawkins to the West Indies on the ill-fated voyage ofÂ 1567â1568, in the course of which the principals lost all the vessels of their small fleet at Vera Cruz except the ones they personally commanded. InÂ 1570 Drake obtained a privateering commission from Queen Elizabeth under Â p467Â which he made two profitable raids in the West Indies and the Caribbean area before starting out inÂ 1577 on his famous voyage to the Pacific. From September,Â 1578, until near the end of that year, he continued his seizure of ships along the coast of Chile. See SirÂ JulianÂ S. Corbett, Drake and the Tudor Navy (NewÂ York, London [etc.], 1899), and William Wood, Elizabethan Sea Dogs (New Haven, 1921), pp95â195, 221â229. See also Henry Raup Wagner, SirÂ Francis Drake's Voyage Around the World, its Aims and its Achievements (SanÂ Francisco, 1926).

Alberto Edwards Vives (1874â1934) was born in Valparaiso. He held a minor official position in the revolution ofÂ 1891, became an attorney inÂ 1896, was elected as deputy inÂ 1909, and became chief of the statistical office ten years later. As such he was in charge of the Census ofÂ 1920, and at different dates â 1914, 1915, 1926 â was minister of the treasury. He edited the writings of J.Â J.Â Vallejo (see p275). For a sketch of his life and outstanding contributions see Rev.Â chil. deÂ hist. yÂ geog., LXXIV (Jan.âApril,Â 1933), 5â64. See also F,Â III,Â 33.

Mariano EgaÃ±a Fabres (1793â1846) was born in Santiago, finished his study of law at the age of eighteen, and shortly thereafter was made secretary of the junta representativa of the sovereignty of Chile. After Rancagua he went into captivity with his father to Juan FernÃ¡ndez. After his return he became fiscal agent of the court of appeals and held other offices under the government. During the years 1824â1829 he was minister plenipotentiary in various European countries. InÂ 1830 he was made minister of the interior but refused the office, preferring to act as fiscal agent of the supreme court. InÂ 1831 he was elected to the chamber of deputies, became its president inÂ 1836, and in addition was plenipotentiary to Peru. He later acted as minister of justice untilÂ 1841. He played a leading part in framing the Constitution ofÂ 1833. â E,Â XIX,Â 170; F,Â III,Â 39â41.

Juan EgaÃ±a Riesco (1769â1860) was born in Lima of a Chilean father and a Peruvian mother. He was graduated in jurisprudence from the University of SanÂ Marcos in Lima, and took up his residence in Chile near the end of the century. He became the chief legislator of the early years of the republic; and he also devoted considerable attention to the education of youth, being one of the founders of the National Institute. His son, Mariano EgaÃ±a, collaborated with him in various important matters of legislation. â F,Â III,Â 36â37. See also AmunÃ¡tegui Solar, Bosquejo histÃ³rico, pp10,Â 11.

Juan SebastiÃ¡n deÂ Elcano (1476â1526) was a native of Guetaria (GuipÃºzcoa). Accustomed from his youth to a seafaring life, he embarked with Magellan inÂ 1519, and during the early part of the voyage Â p468Â alternately opposed and supported his chieftain. After Magellan's death, Elcano took charge of the two remaining ships of the squadron and conducted one successfully back to Spain, thus completing the first circumnavigation of the globe. For this feat and for its probable value in the spice trade, he was rewarded by a coat of arms representing a globe, set off by two clove buds and the inscription Primus CircumdedistiÂºÂ Me. He was one of the commissioners appointed by Spain to settle the dispute with Portugal over the Spice Islands. InÂ 1525, as second in command, he joined the expedition of GarcÃ­a Jofre deÂ Loaisa, bound for the Spice Islands but, separating from his leader at the Strait of Magellan, he claimed to have discovered the open sea below the tip of the continent. He rejoined Loaisa, and after a stormy passage of fifty-one days the two passed through the strait into an equally stormy Pacific. Loaisa perished from the hardships of the voyage in July,Â 1526, and Elcano aÂ month later. The Spanish government never paid to his mother the salary due him, but inÂ 1671 an admirer dedicated a tomb for him in his native town. InÂ 1800 and inÂ 1869 monuments were erected there in his honor. â E,Â XIX,Â 496â498.

Alonso deÂ Ercilla yÂ ZÃºÃ±iga (1533â1594), born in Madrid, was the son of a noted jurist who died when the poet was hardly aÂ year old. His widowed mother became a lady in waiting to Empress Isabella, wife of CharlesÂ V. As a boy Ercilla early became a page to PhilipÂ II and journeyed with the prospective monarch through Flanders, France, Germany, and England. In Spain he met and conversed with the leading conquerors of Mexico and Peru. He was in London with PhilipÂ II when that prince received tidings of Valdivia's death. He accompanied JerÃ³nimo deÂ AldereteÂ (q.v.) when that leader started for America and continued on to Lima after his superior's death. He arrived in Chile with Hurtado deÂ Mendoza, inÂ 1557, and was commissioned as captain; but, when in the following year an altercation arose between him and a fellow officer, he was banished from that colony. Despite this rigorous penalty Ercilla, upon his return to Spain, regained the favor of PhilipÂ II, to whom he dedicated his famous epic. The first part of LaÂ araucana appeared inÂ 1569, the second inÂ 1578, and the third inÂ 1590. The work follows Ariosto in spirit and is worthy a place beside OsÂ Lusiadas of Camoens. InÂ 1571 the poet became knight of the Order of Santiago and later served as gentleman in waiting to LeopoldÂ II of Austria. â M,Â pp254â272; Coester, The Literary History of Spanish America (NewÂ York, 1916), pp6â10.​g

Fernando ErrÃ¡zuriz (1771â1841) was a member of the junta that succeeded O'Higgins who, like many other men of the period, suffered persecution after Rancagua. He was a member of the convention ofÂ Â p469Â 1822 and for many years senator, becoming president of the senate. He served three different times as president adÂ interim of the republic. â E,Â XX,Â 543.

Federico ErrÃ¡zuriz Echaurren (1850â1901) became an advocate at the age of twenty-three but never practiced law. He preferred the simple but elegant life of the great Chilean landowner, an occupation which he combined for nearly thirty years with service in congress. Professedly a liberal, he made little of political principles but utilized his knowledge of human nature to advance his personal fortune. He served as minister of war inÂ 1890 and for aÂ few months inÂ 1894 was minister of justice. As deputy inÂ 1891 he exerted himself to amplify the law extending pardon to the Balmacedists. Elected a senator inÂ 1894, he but also two years later a vigorous campaign for the presidency. He succeeded in defeating his more austere rival through unlimited promises and the lavish use of funds, but needed the decision of a court of honor to gain the office by the narrow majority of two votes. He was a careful but not distinguished executive. The most important act of his administration was the settlement of boundary disputes with Argentina.
